dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bird's-eye view. We circle lazily above the forest. Through a break in the trees, we catch an occasional glim of a prostrate form on the ground. As the circling camera gets closer we see that the form is a human body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bead of sweat trickles down her cheek. Then: a blinding flash of light obliterates her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tear wells in Puff's eye and runs down his face. Anothe blinding flash of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know what sorry means  anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nathan speaks, a trickle of blood drips down his face  from his out-of-frame forehead. Another blinding flash of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a frenetic hand-held shot as Lila is pulled from a p car and dragged into the precinct house. Cameras flash.  Reporters shout questions. Lila attempts to shield her fa from view, but she is handcuffed and can only manage to h her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ratty interrogation room. Institutional green walls. Beat-up file cabinets. Dark. A bit of fluorescent light s in through the frosted glass door. Lila, thirties, sits a the end of a long table. A reel-to-reel tape recorder whi in front of her. She is smoking. Three fat, mean-looking  cops sit in shadows at the other end of the table. One of the cops eyes her lasciviously. Lila's hand shakes as she brings the cigarette to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sorry. So I spend the rest  of my life in jail. So what? I've  been in jail my whole life anyway. A  jail of blood and tissue and coursing  hormones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the cops sighs and massages the bridge of his nose It's going to be a long night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a jail called the human body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lascivious cop smiles lasciviously at Lila's referenc to "human body."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My soul held prisoner in this reeking,  stench-ridden bag of bones and  entrails. A bag of feces and piss  and fibroid cysts in my tits and  precancerous moles on my sun-damaged  back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lascivious cop gags, then vomits on the floor. Lila d on her cigarette, calmer now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least now I'll be able to blame  the state, not God, for my  incarceration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff, thirties, dirty, scraggly hair and beard but in a c business suit, testifies before a congressional committee The auditorium is filled with reporters and spectators. P sits in front of a microphone, counsel at his side. He po himself a glass of water, drinks, clears his throat, then speaks: stentorian, confident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry, gentlemen, sorry for all  of us. Your's is a complicated, sad  world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a revelation to the assembled crowd. People whisp to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I never knew that. I was living  a life of simplicity, of purity,  when I was ripped out of my Eden and  immersed in this harshness. Some  would argue that the life I was living  was not a human life at all. And,  gentlemen, I don't have any clever  retort. I am not a philosopher. The  only thing I know is that I am sorry,  sorry for my expulsion from Eden,  sorry for my Lila rotting in her  jail cell, and sorry for Nathan...  rotting in his grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, thirties, in a white robe, sits alone at a white  table. Everything is white except for an oozing bullet wo in Nathan's temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know what sorry means  anymore. It's odd. When I was alive  I knew -- maybe it was all I knew --  but here sorry is meaningless. Love  is meaningless. Jealousy is  meaningless. Ambition is meaningless.  Everything that motivated my every  breath while I was alive is  meaningless now. (beat) I guess that's how I can be sure I'm  really dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila watches the slowly churning tape recorder reels, fix The cop who vomited is mopping it up. The other two are  sipping coffee. Lila talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My story begins when I was twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checks watch) Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got that faded, "memory" look. Twelve year old Lila  hurries home from school, books clutched to her chest. Other kids walk along the street in pairs or groups, laug and chatting. Lila walks alone, a worried scowl on her fa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something terrible happened when I  was twelve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colors are still muted. It looks to be somewhere in the e 70's based on the preponderance of Bay City Rollers poste on the wall. Twelve year old Lila enters the room, closes the door, locks it, rattles the doorknob to make sure tha the door is really locked. She draws the shades. She pull some t-shirts from her dresser drawer and stuffs them int the space between the bottom of the door and the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled) Hey, no fair!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop dead, Eric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila stands nervously in front of the full-length mirror her closet door. She takes a deep breath and begins to  unbutton her shirt, watching herself carefully in the mir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something terrible started to happen  to my body when I was twelve. My  mother said because of it I would  never be able to get a man, so I  should get used to the idea of  dedicating my life to the pursuit of  knowledge, or religion... or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila's shirt is now unbuttoned. She pulls it open. She is wearing a training bra over the very beginning of breast  buds. On the chest above the bra, and on her stomach belo it, is hair. Dark curly hair. She stares at it, touches i cautiously. Then she starts to cry. She crouches into a b and weeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old fashioned office. Twelve year old Lila sits on the  examination table, her shirt off. An elderly male doctor  touches the hair, fingers it. Her mother looks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the mother) It's hormonal. Nature is a funny and  complex thing. It could get worse  with time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Lila turns to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time I was twenty I looked  like an ape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop who vomited, gags again. Lila stares at him. Her  face is hard, blank. She stubs out her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff testifies before the committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think there's anyone in the  world who doesn't know by now that I  was raised in the wilderness by an  ape. Well, to be fair, by a man who  thought himself an ape, but it amounts  to the same thing gentlemen, does it  not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has a faded, "memory" look also. A naked, bearded, d middle-aged man and a naked, dirty ten year old Puff walk along like apes, crouched over and dragging their knuckle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father escaped from a New Jersey  mental institution in 1963.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's raining and deserted. Puff's father, in pajamas, com tearing around the corner. He runs crazily towards the ca waving his arms, puffing out his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had been committed the previous  year after applying one too many  times at our local zoo for the job  of "apprentice ape."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff's father passes a newspaper vending machine, stops,  goes back and examines the headline. It reads: President  Kennedy Assassinated. Puff's father looks heavenward and  clutches at his temples in despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father saw what the human race  had come to while he was... in  captivity. He felt something had to  be done to create a better world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff's father climbs out a second story window with a sma bundle in his arms. He runs off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stole little me from my mother,  his ex-wife, and raised me, with  love and tenderness and respect, as  an ape like himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff looks pointedly at the congressman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apes don't assassinate their  presidents, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The congressmen are shamed: they look down, they take not they mumble instructions to the assistants seated behind  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An adult Puff and his now older father sit on the forest  floor and pick bugs off each other and eat them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until quite recently I believed myself  to be an ape, although I didn't know  specifically what type. Apes don't  think in terms of type.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff testifies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be argued, gentlemen, that  apes don't even know that they are  apes. In retrospect, however, I'd  say that I was a pygmy chimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff holds up an illustration of a pygmy chimp. Several  reporters run from the room: a scoop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan talks to nobody in particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to say I always hated apes.  Of course I don't any longer. I don't  even know what hate means now. But  while alive, I hated apes. I blame  my parents. I mean, I don't blame  them. I don't know what blame is,  really, anymore, but I think they  influenced me in my ape-hating  tendencies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faded colors. Ten year old Nathan in a bow tie and shortp suit walks along with his uptight, British parents. They arrive at the ape pen. Nathan is excited. He jumps u and down. The apes jump up and down also.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monkeys! Look, mama, monkeys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clamping down on his  shoulder) Nathan, those are not monkeys. Those  are apes. Mountain Gorillas to be  precise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a commotion off screen. Two uniformed attendants drag Puff's father, straitjacketed and kicking and scream like an ape, past Nathan and his parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a human being! I am an  animal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, his father, and the other zoo patrons look on  curiously, a little frightened. Nathan's mother chooses t ignore it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And furthermore... Tell him, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) Uh... (then by rote) We must never act like apes, son.  For you see, The ape is our closest  biological relative -- specifically  the pygmy chimp. (holds up the same  illustration of a  pygmy chimp that  Puff showed the  congressional  committee) A single chromosome separates us.  But you know what truly separates us  from the apes, what makes us better  than apes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, papa. What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Culture. Civilization. Refinement.  If we do not have these as humans,  then we might as well be living in  pens and throwing our feces about,  masturbating in public... (beat, a reverie) ...sniffing red swollen female rump...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila lights a new cigarette with her spent one. She drags

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I had sexual urges. I had the  urge to merge, officers. Inside I  was 100% Grade A female. (laughs derisively) But what self-loathing I felt! Who  would have someone as repulsive, as  unladylike as me? I did everything I  could to shield the world from this  repulsiveness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stockings hang over the shower curtain rod. The window sh is drawn. Towels are stuffed in the space under the door. twenty year old naked Lila is covered with shaving cream, face to feet. She is shaving. There is a pounding on the  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila, what are you doing in there? I  need to get ready for my date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing! I'll be out in a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Lila freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'll just... (stops in her tracks  when she sees Lila) What the...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is mortified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is sitting in her bathrobe on her bed and staring ou the window. There is a bit of shaving cream behind her ea Her roommate runs back and forth getting ready for her da

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why you didn't tell me  about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's embarrassing, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not so bad. (beat) So, it just keeps growing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Natalie. It's hair. It grows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't jump down my throat. I'm  just trying to help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that helping, Natalie? How  exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you're going to be like  that... You should be appreciative  that I'm interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, because I'm a freak and you are  beautiful, and you are being nice  enough to come down to my freak,  nonbeautiful level and act concerned  about my repulsive troubles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pegged) You're fucked up, Lila. (out the door) Why don't you fucking try electrolysis  or something? Figure it out for  chrissake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams. Lila hugs her knees to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At sixty dollars an hour, electrolysis  was not a feasible solution. I  explored my alternatives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve year old Lila walks sadly through an art museum. s looks at various old portraits of men. She studies their  facial hair. When she turns a corner, she is shocked to s a large Renaissance painting of a naked woman entirely co with fur. She hurries to it. She looks at the placard nex to the painting. It is a painting of Mary Magdalene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember once coming across a  painting of Mary Magdalene entirely  covered with fur. I guess that's  where I got the idea that maybe the  Catholic Church might be a place  that encouraged excessive hair growth  in its women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila, in a nun's habit, is on her knees praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I became a nun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavenly Father... (sighs) ...please let this hair go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my prayers were always so selfish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of naked women dance and chat around a campfire. Lila is there, pretty hairy. So are many of the other wom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried being a lesbian separatist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) A woman without a man / Is like a  fish without a bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I guess I just wasn't attracted  to women, even hostile, man-hating,  hairy ones who wore sensible shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila, in a full beard, sits on a throne before a crowd of gawking, dumb-looking, mouth-breathing children. Next to on a separate stage is a sour-looking, middle-aged midget man sitting on a throne, staring blankly into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a while I was a professional  circus freak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila, in a Santa suit, with beard sprayed white, sits on throne in front of a crowd of gawking, dumb-looking, mout breathing children. One of them is on her lap. Next to he sits the sour midget, dressed in an elf suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the holiday season, they made  us wear costumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (depressed) Ho ho ho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid pulls Lila's beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! You little fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aside from the great dental, this  occupation was not pleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila walks home. She's wrapped in winter clothing, but we can still see a bit of her white beard. It's snowing. The street is deserted. She spots a lighted window, she peers in. It's a warm family scene. Large group of chatting,  laughing people. Fire in the fireplace. Big turkey on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say the holidays are difficult  for a lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila looks down the street and sees dozens of lonely-look people peering forlornly in warmly lit windows. Some on  ladders to peer in second-floor windows. Lila sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is lit with candles. Lila finishes shaving herse all over. Then she takes the double-edged blade out of th razor and climbs into the a bathtub filled with warm wate She is about to slice her wrists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I decided there was something poetic  about killing myself with a razor  blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the shelf next to the tub a little gray mouse watches intently. At first she is startled, but then she and the  creature seem to be communing. His little black beady eye reflect the light. Lila starts to cry. She puts down the  blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila wipes a tear from her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way that mouse looked at me.  There was no judgement. It didn't  care if I had hair all over my body.  I was just what I was. I felt so  free. Do you understand what I'm  saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops look up, on the spot. It seems their minds were  elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something about a mouse, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a tent in a clearing. A smoking campfire. There is rustling inside the tent. Lila steps out naked. She is co with fur. She pours a cup of coffee, and stands, comforta in her skin, watching the world around her. Squirrels jump from tree to tree, birds look down at her. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birds and squirrels and rocks and  trees didn't seem to judge my hair.  I felt at peace when there were no  humans around. I figured out a way  to spend as much time as possible  with no people around. I became a  nature writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila picks up a pad and pen from a rock, sits on the rock and writes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman under a hair drier reads a book intently. We see first sentence of the chapter: "Last night I almost died this mountain top." We hear Lila's dramatic reading compe with the very loud sound of the hair drier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night I almost died on this  mountain top, and the irony is I had  never felt more alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a violent, violent storm. The hair drier drone h turned into the explosive noise of rain beating down in s and wind howling at fifty miles an hour. Branches crack.  Lila's tent blows over, revealing her huddled there with sleeping bag wrapped around her like a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it was coming when in late  afternoon, a thunderhead drifted  over, sneaking in like kids through  the back door of a movie theater,  forced casual. It turned the sky a  queer shade of green. A green that  said "watch out, baby, this is gonna  hurt like hell." I could've  hightailed, but that would be  cheating. Part of the Nature  experience is recognizing its mastery  over you, your smallness in the face  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning hits a tree nearby. It falls with a smack  practically on top of Lila. She screams, then defiantly  stands, throwing off the sleeping bag. The wind and rain  whip her hair around her head. She laughs with amazing gu and raise her arms like a runner winning a marathon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Nietzsche said, what does not  kill me makes me stronger, and that  goes double if you're a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see many copies of a book entitled "Wind in my Hair" b Lila Jute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I became a successful nature writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a woman under a hair drier reading "Wind in my Hai We pull back to see that a long row of women under hair d are reading Lila's book. They all stand defiantly, proudl knocking their hair driers up and back as they do. The blowing hair driers whip the women's wet hair around  their heads. The blowing hair drier drone is unbearably l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I became a famous nature writer.  I said to myself, fuck humanity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big display of the book "Fuck Humanity" by Lila Jute. A long line of women with beautifully coiffured hair snakes out of the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I became a recluse. I had a  menagerie of animals at my house.  They loved me because I was me. They  loved me on the days I shaved. They  loved me on the days I didn't. For a  while this was enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila lies in bed tapping on a lap top. A dog lies with he and licks her knee. She seems to enjoy it, and gets lost a reverie. The dog morphs into a handsome man, kissing he knee and working his way up her thigh and under her night Lila is getting seriously hot and bothered. Her head loll But the reverie dissipates and the man turns back into a rooting around her crotch with his cold nose. She pushes away. The dejected dog gets off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time I was thirty I was very,  very horny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila gets out of bed and studies herself in the mirror. S brushes her hands against her hairy body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to have a man in my... life.  At any cost. I would become what I  needed to become to achieve this. I  would become a hairless lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mirror image of Lila shimmers and turns into Lila wit no body hair. Lila all made-up and with a smart new hairs She assumes a coquettish pose and smiles cutely at hersel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was rich enough for electrolysis  by this time, so I began the long  arduous process of having each  inappropriate hair burned out of my  body at the root.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila talks. One of the cops is doodling. One is picking w from his ear with a pencil. One is reading a paperback no under the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is when everything changed, and  this is where my confession really  begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila lies shirtless on a table while Rose, her fifty year old electrologist, works on her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Progress!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, honey. Getting to be smooth  smooth smooth all over. Smooth as a  baby's butt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love it, Rose. I'm getting to be a  real girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still in the market for a real  boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always. Ow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Cause there's this guy. My brother  knows him. Might be right up your  alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me. I could use someone up my  alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing dumb) I don't get that. Is that sexual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handsome, thirties, psychologist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loves animals? Ouch. Must love  animals, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loves animals. Loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow it came up that you were a  friend of mine. Mr. handsome, animal- loving psychologist said he would  love to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Your brother didn't tell  him about the nature of our  relationship, did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother is discreet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing her hand  over her jaw) Won't he be able to tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother says the guy's a thirty- five year old virgin, so maybe he  won't know how women usually feel.  Plus he's got bad eyesight, almost  legally blind, which is helpful in  this situation. Plus he's got an  extremely small penis, of which he  is "mortifyingly ashamed", so chances  are he'll be so grateful for any non- judgmental attention, that he'll be  yours forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, he must be really close to your  brother to tell him such personal  stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well my brother is his shrink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a chi-chi place. Lila sits at a table with Nathan,  fastidious in dress and manner. There is an awkward first silence. She sneaks a glance at his crotch. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meditations on a Banana Slug was a  delightful read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. I love slugs. All  slugs, not just banana slugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're so even keel. They forge  ahead with slow determination. They  don't get distracted or side-tracked.  They don't care what they look like. They don't care that people look at  them and go, "Ewww. A slug."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't seem to be especially ego  driven, this is true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to respect that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to say that I'm not there  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slugdom. Sluggishness. Whatever you'd  call it. I'm not there yet. I still  have many human characteristics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not necessarily a bad thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I suppose not. But still. One  would like to move along. To move  beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure we can escape our  natures. Believe me I've tried. I'm  not even so sure anymore that we  should want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love that you said that. It makes  me feel a bit lighter. I've been  rather heavy lately. Thinking about  my childhood. Realizing how much a  product I am of my upbringing. (beat, cautiously) I've been seeing someone. A therapist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning surprise) You are a therapist, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no. I'm a psychologist, but I do  research. I'm a behaviorist. I work  with animals. Mice at the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't perform any of those  dreadful torture experiments, Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavens no. My work now is... Right  now I'm teaching mice... well, table  manners, to be candid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat. doesn't know  what to say) How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite well, really. It's a lot of  work. A lot of reinforcement, mostly  positive. Right now I've gotten two  of my subjects to use napkins. Tiny  napkins of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paper or cloth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't think me daft. It's  important work. It's part of a larger  sociological experiment. I'm federally  funded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the larger experiment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my thesis that if table manners  can be taught to mice, they can be  taught to humans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going out on a limb, aren't you,  Nathan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speech) The truth is most people don't have  table manners today. And when the  foundations of civilized society  crumble and disappear, civilized  society in its entirely follows  closely at its heels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stridently) Courtesy, decorum, manners, are all  sadly lacking from our daily  intercourse. Rudeness, vulgarity,  meanness are the norm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are animals after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ergo if I can teach table manners to  mice, I can teach them to humans. If  I can teach table manners to humans,  I can save the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan blushes. Lila stares at him for a long moment. Her thoughts are unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila lies on her back. Rose works on her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really like him, Rose. He's so... (searching) ...passionate about his work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother says he likes you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Says he likes you even more  than he likes his own mother. And  according to my brother Nathan's  abormally close with his mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I began going to a therapist when I  was in my thirties, because I felt  that I wasn't enjoying life the way  my friends were. (beat) After a time my childhood came up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is another sepia scene. Nathan as a ten year old sits the table with his parents. There is a bowl of salad in f of each of them. Everyone's head is bowed in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, we thank you for this bountiful  gift we are about to receive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes open, and young Nathan reaches for a fork to eat the salad. He grabs the wrong fork. Mother's eyes widen in ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, no! My God! (disappointed) Oh, Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is the wrong fork, young man. (to father) Harold, tell the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is the wrong fork, young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicky) I'll use the right one. I'm sorry. I  forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold, tell the boy more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late. Go to your room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harold! Tell the boy again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at mother) No "buts." Go to your room now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at father) And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And think about what you've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adult Nathan sits on the couch, dabbing at his eyes. Wendall, his therapist sits across from him and writes  something in his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do you think maybe this early  childhood indoctrination has something  to do with your interest in table  manners in the present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan thinks long and hard about this. He seems to be re straining, squinting his eyes. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendall nods and scribbles something on his pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendall looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's white. People in lab coats hustle back and f Nathan, also in a lab coat, is hovering over a Lucite  encasement. Inside we see two white mice, both attached t electrodes. They sit in little chairs at a little table. front of each of them is a little plate of salad and thre forks of varying size under Lucite domes. Nathan nods to his pretty French assistant, Gabrielle, wh presses a button. The Lucite domes over the salads lift. Tentatively both mice reach for a fork. There is a tiny p of velcro on each mouse's paw and a tiny piece of velcro each of the forks. The first mouse picks the correct fork and stabs it into the salad and eats happily, relieved. T second mouse picks the wrong fork. Nathan presses a butto which sends the mouse flying off his chair with an electr shock. The correct mouse keeps eating, unconcerned. Natha makes a note in his notebook. Gabrielle watches Nathan as he writes, enchanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is elegantly set, candlelit. Lila sits at it wh Nathan fusses in the kitchenette. Something classical waf over from the stereo in the living room. Nathan places a  salad in front of Lila and sits across from her with his salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look wonderful. I'm on top of  the world tonight, Lila. Work is  going splendidly and my personal  life is ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila picks up a fork from the inside of her setting, not outside. Nathan blinks. Lila tastes the salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um-mmm. Oh Nathan, this salad is  delish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clenched teeth) My God! The fork! The fork!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (strangely) Tell her, Harold... (stops himself) It's just that... It's nothing. It's  just that the outside fork is the  salad fork. One goes from the outside  in as the dinner progresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry. (picks up correct  fork) I'm sorry, Nathan. I never really  learned those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (forced casual) No biggie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long silence as they both eat the salad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, this is good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry that I became so upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. I'm really backward  in certain areas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, blurting) It's only that I really enjoy your  company and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really enjoy my company?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat, blurting) Please don't talk with food in your  mouth, Lila. Please. You're so pretty  and it only mars your... I'm sorry.  I'm being critical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan pounds his forehead with his fist. Lila waves her  hand to indicate that it's fine. She doesn't say anything because she's chewing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that I have some  peculiarities, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like you, too, Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah (beat) But I have some peculiarities also.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (happily) I don't care. I don't care! (then, concerned) Like what, for example?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila takes a deep breath, about to go into it, thinks bet of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan smiles, relieved. Lila smiles back. Nathan recoils slightly, skittishly half-points to his bared teeth. Apparently there's a piece of food stuck in Lila's teeth. She closes her mouth, runs her tongue over her teeth, smi again, mouth closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is doing Lila's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother says things are going  really well between you and Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot believe how in love I am  with this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so cute. I even like his cute  little penis. It's like a little  pig's penis or something. (beat) Rose, we connect on every level.  I've finally found someone I can  feel completely safe with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't throw that away. I had that  once with a guy. But I threw it away  for a cheap thrill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One night stand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I married a midget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marrying a midget was a cheap thrill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he wasn't really a midget. He  was on the cusp of midgethood. That's  what made it cheap. Had he been an  actual midget, there would've been  nothing cheap about it, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know you were into that  sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you, honey, midgets are  the best kept secret in male  companionship. They're portable.  They're controllable. They're eager.  And they're exactly the right height  for a little covert oral fun on the  dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams with delight,  then:) I have a friend you might like to  meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three foot one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be still my crotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, Nathan's no midget, but he's  asked me to move in with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. My brother told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I think I'm going to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mulling it over) Stand on a stepladder sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila moved in with me. Did I love  her? I thought so. But from my new  vantage point I realize that love is  nothing more than a messy  conglomeration of need, desperation,  fear of death, insecurity about penis  size, and the self-involved, ego  driven need to collect other people's  hearts. Not that I judge it. (puts head in hands.  beat. looks up) Listen, I don't want to be dead yet.  Is there any way to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan looks around for some sign of another person. Ther is nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I suppose not. (beat) No biggie. Anyway, Lila moved in. We  had our problems, but we both wanted  love so badly, we turned a blind  eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, Lila, and Nathan's parents (looking very, very ol sit at the dining room table. Salad is about to be eaten, and everyone glances sideways over at Lila, waiting for h to make her move. She reaches for the wrong fork, correct herself and picks the salad fork. Nathan breathes a sigh relief. His mother looks disappointed, clucks. They eat i silence. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lovely to finally meet you, Mr.  and Mrs. Bronfman. I've heard so  much about you and I've seen you in  photographs from Nathan's childhood,  but it's nice to meet you in the  flesh. I must say, you look exactly  the same as in the photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, Mother and Father, you  look very, very old. You look  terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother and father touch their faces reflexively, then look at each other and laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him, Harold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, your mother and I are doing a  production of The Gin Game at the  local community theater. We forgot  to take off our make-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mother and father laugh again. Then they pull at thei latex faces. The wrinkles come off. And they look exactly they did in the flashback scene, albeit a bit pink-faced. There is another pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkward) Goodness, you two look exactly as  you did in those old photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cold) Yes, so you mentioned earlier, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changing the subject) Lila's a nature writer, mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love nature. As long as it stays  in the zoo where it belongs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The father and Nathan laugh at mother's joke. Lila joins weakly, against her better judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lila) Don't you agree, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course she does, mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan is in bed, in starched pajamas. He lies on his bac under perfect covers and stares straight up at the ceilin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissy) I'll be out in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about my parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't seem sorry when you were  laughing at all your mother's stupid,  tasteless, cruel animal jokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was simply attempting to keep the  evening light. You know that I feel  similarly to you about nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. (beat) I simply love the... naturalness of  it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila emerges from the bathroom, radiant, hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you? Oh do you, darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why certainly!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila happily leaps into bed. She smothers Nathan with kis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, darling. I'm so relieved. Let's  celebrate with a long hike in the  woods tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (oh shit) That's a great idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be wonderful! I'll show you my  old stomping grounds!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific. Can't wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan kisses her ear. He looks confused, sticks his fing behind her ear, and pulls it out with a dab of shaving cr on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaving cream?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. (beat) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan drives. He's dressed in spanking new, freshly star safari clothes, big shiny new hiking boots. Lila sits in front passenger seat. She is dressed in a costume identic to Nathan's, but, as opposed to Nathan, she seems awkward it. She fidgets in it, straightens it, sighs, comes to te with it, and looks dreamily out the window at the passing trees. She is home. That's all that matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, did you bring the insect  repellent lotion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Oh, and the sun block?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What SPF, sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectomundo! We are ready! (beat) Say, wouldn't it be wonderful to  have an insect repellent lotion that  also worked as a sun block? Think of  all the time one would save.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll get Johannsen in  chemistry on that. (beat) Oh! Did you bring the first aid kit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could call it "Quit Bugging Me,  Sunny." (laughs a lot) Get it? Sunny. S-u-n-n-y.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs appreciatively) That's very funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff testifies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, gentlemen, one day I saw  something I hadn't seen since my  father died in a freak accident  involving a rotted log and four  thousand bees stinging his head... I  saw other human beings. They chattered  away at each other in what appeared  to be gibberish. Later I learned it  was English. Now I wonder if perhaps  my initial assessment hadn't been  correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff's POV: Through some brush we watch Nathan and Lila  hiking. We hear Puff's loud heavy breathing and, in the  distance, the relentless gibberish chatter of Nathan and  Lila. Puff moves. Lila glances over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a flash of white. I ruled out  deer immediately. Too... upright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're with Lila and Nathan now. Lila has stopped and is  peering into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Too... upright. Might've been a  person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) It might behoove us to turn back at  this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila walks in the direction of the sighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not budging) If it's a person, why should we go  see it? It's not like it's nature or  anything. It's just a person. (beat) Sometimes people who live in the  woods don't want to be seen. They  live in the woods because they're  anti-social, Lila. We have to respect  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila trudges through the brush. Nathan follows. Better th being left behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the way to get ticks, Lila.  This is it. Bingo! Lyme Disease!  You've hit the nail on the head here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is in her element. Her whole demeanor has changed. She is tracking. She sniffs the breeze, cocks her head, m stealthily. Then she sheds her clothes, almost shaking th off, like a dog shaking off some cute costume his owner h dressed him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh for God's sa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila turns her head and glares at Nathan. There is an ani fierceness in her eye that shuts him up instantly. She turns back to pursue her prey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff testifies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had never seen anything like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff's POV: We see a naked Lila looking in our general  direction, but not seeing us. The sun dapples her body. She moves closer and closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an ape as I had never seen  before. Like me, yet different in  certain essential details. And all  at once I felt a heat pass through  me. My heart raced. Gentlemen, I  wanted to touch her, to caress her,  to be one with her. I had urges and  desires I could not explain. I felt  overwhelmed by the power this strange  creature had over me, and so I did  what any animal would do when it  comes across an animal of superior  strength...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cops are transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bolted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are with Lila. She creeps along, when suddenly a tan,  muscular figure tears out from behind a tree and runs,  practically on all fours, through the dense underbrush. Lila follows, almost as agile as the forest creature. Nathan just stands there. The chase continues. There is a great deal of heaving and panting. Puff shimmies up a lar tree. Lila follows. Puff leaps from branch to branch. Lila follows easily. Puff swings from a vine. So does Lil Finally they come to the end of the trees, a clearing. Th is no nowhere for Puff to leap. Lila is with him in the t They are crouched, bloody, heaving, on separate branches, staring at each other. After a long moment, Lila speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff cocks his head. The high timbre of her voice surpris him, pleases him, but he doesn't understand the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand my language, do  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff looks at his crotch. Apparently there is some activi down there. Lila, following his eyes, glances down there  also.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) I take it back, you do understand my  language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff grabs for his crotch and begins to play with himself distractedly, looking at her all the while. He falls out the tree. Lila gasps. Branches crack and snap as he passe through them and then there is an unpleasant thud when he hits the forest floor. Lila shimmies down the tree, and k by Puff. He is unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan comes limping through the brush. Somehow his safar suit and boots are as clean and pressed as they were in t car. He is carrying Lila's clothes. Somehow he has had ti to neatly fold them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Is he dead? Please put  something on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila looks up at icily at Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll catch cold. It's cold. (beat) What do you suppose he is, a  survivalist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's feral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping back) Feral? Don't touch him! He might be  diseased! He might... My God, rabies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks perfectly fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should go. Please. Before  he wakes up and, I don't know, eats  us, or whatever feral things do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand you. This is  fascinating and you just want to run  away. I mean, here we have a human  being totally uncontaminated by  civilization, totally free, and all  you want to do is run back to your...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking) Actually, I just had an amusing  thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing) Feral, huh? Totally uncontaminated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at him. He doesn't understand  English. He moves like an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's perfect!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, what the hell are you talking  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doing a little dance) Forget mice! Actually forget guinea  pigs, cats, monkeys, and chimps also.  I'm on to stage five: The human  subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. You can't take him from his  home, Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ranting) Don't you see? He's my Tabula Rasa,  my Eliza Dolittle. He's my ticket to  the top of the Behaviorist food chain.  He's going to make me famous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't allow you. It's wrong. He's  happy here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he, Lila? Is he happy living filthy  and naked alone in this tick infested  wilderness? Never to know the love  of a good woman, never to revel in  the pitter-patter of little feet,  never to read Moby Dick, or marvel  at a Monet, or just sit back after a  day of hard but rewarding work, smoke  a pipe, and wonder about the nature  of reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (weakening resolve) You'd be taking away his freedom,  Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freedom's just another word for  nothing left to lose, Lila, to quote  Janet Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila looks off into the distance, her eyes brimming with  tears. As Nathan continues his speech, we move closer and closer into Lila's eyes. Nathan's voice fades into nothin by the time we dissolve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belonging to something, a person or  a society, is a basic human craving.  We are communal creatures. This poor  soul has no one, nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A naked, very hairy Lila sits by herself on the cliff and watches the sunset. There's a chill in the air and she sh and hugs herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I have no one. Nothing. You  give me this beautiful gift, this  glorious sunset. But with no one to  say "isn't that a beautiful sunset"  to, it becomes meaningless, just  another stupid sunset. They happen  everyday. So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is hovering over the unconscious Puff. Nathan's voic comes back into focus. He is still speechifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what is it that makes us human,  if not the knowledge that we are  indeed human? Think of this poor  soul's education as the greatest  gift we could bestow upon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Grab his feet. We'll throw  him in the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan hovers over the Lucite case with the tiny dinner t in it. His assistant, Gabrielle, presses a button, a door opens, and two white mice scurry in. The male pulls out a chair for the female. The female climbs up on the chair, the male pushes the chair in, then scurries around to the other side of the table and climbs onto his own chair. Th Lucite lid over the silverware and salads lifts and both  mice pick up the proper forks and begin eating. Nathan  scribbles in his notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan looks up. Gabrielle jerks her head in the directio of a very large Lucite case. Inside, Puff, now dressed in diaper and connected to all sorts of electrodes, is stirr Nathan and Gabrielle hurry over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff groggily takes in his surroundings. This is quite a to take in. The white room, the strange apes in strange s his own clothing, the wires. After surveying the scene fo moment, Puff becomes frightened and agitated. He tries to escape. Not understanding Lucite, he smashes  into it, again and again. He tears at his diaper. Nathan  gives a nod to Gabrielle, who presses a button on a panel An electric shock sends Puff flying. He lies on the floor confused and dazed. After a moment, he gets up and again  crashes into the Lucite. Nathan gives the signal to Gabri and once again she shocks Puff. He once again gets up and crashes against the Lucite. Again he is shocked. He gets again, and is about to crash against the Lucite, but he t better of it, and squats in place, immobilized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) Only three shocks. A chimp takes  fifteen. This is going to be tres  simple, no, Gabrielle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in love with Nathan) Oui, doctor, oui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Puff) Good morning... (to Gabrielle) We need a name for him, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You decide. Today is your day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? My day? Well, I had a sweet  little mongrel puppie named Puff  when I was a girl. This one reminds  me of my dog, all shaggy! So cute! (giggles girlishly) I loved my doggie very much, monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (charmed) Puff it is then. Puff Bronfman. Is  that okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui. Perfect!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Puff) Good morning, Puff Bronfman. I'm Dr.  Bronfman and this is my assistant  Gabrielle. We're your mommy and daddy  while you are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle likes this concept a great deal. She smiles and moves closer to Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Puff) How about some salad, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle poises her finger above the button. She winks a Nathan. He blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, carrying a brief case, is walking to his car. Gabrielle hurries to catch up to him. Her high heels clic on the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Bronfman! Dr. Bronfman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Hi, Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of breath) Hi. I just wanted to tell you that I  very much enjoy working with you. (blushes) Now I'm embarrassed that I say this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't be. I really enjoy hearing  that. You're a terrific assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merci. I... Do you... would you like  to go get a cup of coffee, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know. I'm actually on  my way to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I am truly embarrassed. Forgive  me. I should not have asked such a  stupid question. I know you are a  very important man and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't be silly. It's just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a foolish little thing. I am  pink in my face, no? It is only that  I have been so lonely lately and...  I am ashamed. I'll see you tomorrow,  okay? Unless... Am I fired now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle pouts. Nathan is charmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan and Gabrielle sit at a romantic little table in a  trendy coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much for accompanying  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have had such a difficult time in  my personal life and you seem to be  such a nice man... but I'm talking  too much again, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so sweet. Oh, why are there  not more men out there like you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle starts to cry softly. Nathan doesn't know what do. His eyes dart around, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle looks up at him appreciatively. She sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know just the right thing to  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches across the table and touches his hand lightly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you're the best assistant  I've ever had... Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I like it when you say my name. Is  that stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, in his pajamas, lies in bed reading. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Be right out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Nathan picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (beat, happily) Oh, hi... Gabrielle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan sits up in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Right, Gabrielle. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Absolutely, Gabrielle. (covering phone,  testily) Someone from work! (into phone) Sorry about that, Gabrielle. Uh-huh.  Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who from work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Excuse me one second, would you,  Gabrielle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan puts down the phone and heads to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it, Nathan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan opens the bathroom door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Lila, when I'm on a work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila turns with a gasp. She has shaving cream all over he chest. Nathan looks stunned. He backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights are low. The room is peppered with lit candles Gabrielle, in a slip, lies on her bed, eating cherries fr a bowl, and listening to Nathan and Lila's conversation o speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hormonal, Nathan. I can't help  it. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your entire body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting electrolysis. It's  working, but it takes time. So  meanwhile I have to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to shave? Like an ape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) Apes don't shave, you son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't quibble. You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Please don't be mad at me  for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mad? I'm I'm... disgusted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the same person I was before you  knew, damn it! Oh God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to think! I have to think!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps and a door slam. Lila is near the phone now and crying in desperate heaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, why... do... I... have...  to... be... like... Oh, no! Oh, shit! (rustling sound, then  into phone) Hello? Hello? Is anyone there? Who's  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle calmly pops another cherry in her mouth and han up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, in his pajamas, drives. His face is set in a furi scowl and he drives fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle drives leisurely. She is calm, a slight smile o her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan paces in front of Puff's Lucite case. Puff watches suspiciously from the corner where he is huddled. The lig are off. But there is a green glow from a couple of exit  signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it. I don't get it. I  don't get it. How could I find myself  in this mess? This is a mess. This  is not a situation I understand.  This is a mess. How do I extricate  myself from this mess? Is my  girlfriend a man? I don't understand.  This is not part of any plan. She  deceived me. She has hair. (beat) But am I being fair? So what if she  has hair? Who am I to judge? I have  hair. (beat) But I'm supposed to have hair. I am  a man. Men are supposed to have hair. (beat) But poor Lila. Think of what she's  had to go through. The courage she's  had to have in the face of this  abomination of nature. I should love  her all the more. I should love every  hair on her body. I mean, she doesn't  mind that I have a mortifyingly  small...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights flick on. Nathan turns with a start. It's  Gabrielle. She's in an overcoat. She gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Doctor. I did not know. I'm sorry  to disturb you. I just came for some  papers I left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle. No, I'm sorry if I startled  you. I came to think. (beat, remembering) God, Did I hang up on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui. Perhaps I called at a bad time.  I am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I just got distracted. I'm so  sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything fine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui. (laughs) Now you've got me talking French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) I was in my p.j.'s when I remembered  I left some papers I need to go over. (opens overcoat to  reveal lingerie) See? I rushed right out of the house. I must look a mess. I'm so  embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken) I'm in my p.j.'s, too. Funny, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff is taken also. His eyes are wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coincidence, yes? (beat) And how is our son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our...? Oh! (laughs, out of control) He seems fine. I guess we woke him.  The lights and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should turn them off. (she does) Maybe I sing him a lullaby my mama  sang to me when I was a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little giddy) When you were a little French girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back in control) That would be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle kneels by Puff's case. Puff crawls over, tries touch her through the Lucite. Gabrielle sings a French  lullaby. It's very sweet. Nathan watches her, looks at he thigh, her hair, the delicate way the tip of her nose mov when she sings. Puff gets drowsy. He curls up on the floo and sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly to Nathan) There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan stares at her, transfixed. She pretends not to not

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we close up, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should just sit for a while.  It's very peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice, yes. I'm glad I ran into  you, both in our silly pajamas. It  is two happy coincidences, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Happy happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet you look so sad. A great man  like you should not be sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine. Life is funny, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle stands. She stretches languorously, revealing a lot of leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't say this, but you're  pretty, Gabrielle. It's  unprofessional, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I always think myself so  ugly. No, not ugly, but plain. A  wallflower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (buying her line) Really? No. Not at all. You're a  very pretty girl. You should know  that. You should be confident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much. Merci. It's very  wonderful to hear a man say such a  nice compliment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. I wouldn't lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle walks slowly by Nathan. He inhales deeply, brea her in. She smiles to herself. He reaches out touches her leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely protesting) Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves into Nathan. She presses her thigh against his  shoulder. Nathan leans forward, kisses her exposed thigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So soft. So smooth. (back to reality) I'm sorry. It's just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soothing) Shh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila is shaving herself all over. Shaving and weeping. There are nicks all over her body. She has no eyebrows an more. The hair on her head is hacked off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan and Gabrielle are lying naked on the floor. Gabrielle rests her head on Nathan's chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that okay? I mean, was I able  to... satisfy you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are an animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Wow! That's that's terrific  to hear from someone so... feminine,  so female.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love being female because it, how  do you say, allows me to be close to  men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you're female. (beat) Do you think our boy witnessed the  primal scene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway it's time he grew up. N'est- ce pa? (sighing, running her  fingers along his  chest) I love chest hair on a man. I know  it isn't fashionable now, hairy men.  But to me it is the very sign of  masculinity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan tenses. Gabrielle looks up innocently at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong, my darling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, my darling. All is right  with the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff watches from his case. Gabrielle smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff testifies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it, gentlemen. I saw the whole  sweaty, passionate, ugly, beautiful  act, and to use the vernacular, I  wanted me some of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The congressmen laugh appreciatively. The laughter is a l too enthusiastic and goes on a little too long. It stops  abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I think I understood from that  moment, that in order to get some, I  would have to do what they said. In  order to experience this primal,  basic, animal thing, I would first  have to become a civilized, prissy,  uptight human. I would have to become  Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The congressmen nod sadly, in recognition of this reality

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puff, in his Lucite case, sits behind a set dinner table. He seems attentive, calm, interested as Nathan teaches hi table manners. Gabrielle stands very close, almost  possessively close, to Nathan. She wears a lab coat, but is unbuttoned, and underneath she is wearing a skin-tight black minidress. She strokes the back of Nathan's head as works with Puff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slow. talking to an  idiot) Excellent, Puff. Now, the lady you're  with excuses herself to go powder  her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wheels turn in Puff's head. He thinks hard. Then he  stands. Gabrielle shrieks and claps happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. Perfect, Puff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan leans over and kisses Gabrielle. Puff watches. He  makes an exaggerated kissy-face, pursing his lips, trying imitate Nathan. The phone rings. Gabrielle pulls herself  away, giggles as Nathan tries to keep her from going, and picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still giggling) Dr. Bronfman's line. Yes. One moment  please. (puts it on hold) Lila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. (takes phone) Hi, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila sits on the couch. Eyebrows are attractively drawn o her face. She wears a very femme blonde wing. Lots of mak up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how's it going today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Making progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, can we talk tonight? You know,  about stuff? Things have been so  strained for the past three weeks,  since you know, and I just want to  talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan, phone cradled between shoulder and ear, puts his  face in his hand. Gabrielle rests a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's fine, honey. We don't  need to talk. Besides I have to work  late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Nathan. I really need this.  You've been working late a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan looks up helplessly at Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, we'll have dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle gets mad, exhales sharply, pulls her hand away. Nathan gives her a pleading look, grabs for her. She move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Okay. Be home around seven.  Bye. (hangs up) What? I'm sorry. What was I supposed  to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) I don't know, Nathan. What are you  supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't abandon somebody because  they have a physical problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny. I thought that's exactly what  you did. You just don't have the  courage to admit it to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan talks. A tear runs down his face, mingles with the blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny. I still feel guilt. Even dead.  One would've hoped... But alas. You  know, I really did love Lila. But  with her... problem... and then when  Gabrielle revealed her feelings. And  Gabrielle was so... conventionally  female. And she had an accent. I was  lost from that moment on. But  Gabrielle was right. I couldn't admit  it to myself, this shallowness of  character, let alone to Lila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila and Nathan eat. Lila is in her new, very feminine ma up, wig, and dress. Her table manners are impeccable, alm robotic. There is an awkward silence

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you seeing somebody else, Nathan?  I just have to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would just be helpful to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, you know, you seem so  distant. And you work late every  night. And we hardly ever have sex,  and when we do, it's... I don't know.  It feels different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just preoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like my new look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's nice. It's really good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying, you know. (starting to cry) I'm trying to be what you want. I  want to be what you want, Nathan.  All I want is to be what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Shh. It's okay. (takes her hand) It's okay, Lila. You're what I want.  You know that. You're exactly what I  want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopefully, sniffing) Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm really trying, you know.  Rosie says maybe only another two  years of the elctrolysis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hard to stomach) That's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've signed up for a ballet class.  And look at my nails! A real girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila holds out her hands. Her finger nails are polished f engine red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great. It's a great color for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Nathan, let's have a baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lila holds and rocks a swaddled baby. She passes it to Na who looks at it and sees that it's a baby monkey. Nathan shudders. Lila looks on lovingly, oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan sits with his head in his hands. Wendall listens  attentively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So anyway, that's the nightmare I've  been having lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
